results.abstract: Op-Ed article by Neil deGrasse Tyson, astrophysicist, says man's accomplishments in space may not yet measure up to Stanley Kubrick's movie, 2001: A Space Odyssey, but we have nonetheless come long way in exploration of space; says greatest challenge to human exploration of space is surviving its biologically hostile environments, and space robots are doing that job, with probes that are monitoring sun, oriting Mars, intercepting comet's tail, orbiting asteroid, orbiting Jupiter and traveling to Saturn; says space robots have beamed back information that fires imagination with prospect of finding life on future missions; diagram (M)
results.snippet: The time has come. The new year is upon us, and there will be no escape from the relentless comparisons between the spacefaring future world we saw in Stanley Kubrick's ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' and the reality of our measly earthbound life in the...
results.lead_paragraph: The time has come. The new year is upon us, and there will be no escape from the relentless comparisons between the spacefaring future world we saw in Stanley Kubrick's ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' and the reality of our measly earthbound life in the real 2001. We don't yet have a lunar base camp, and we have not yet sent hibernating astronauts to Jupiter in outsized space ships, but we have nonetheless come a long way in our exploration of space. People sometimes wax nostalgic over the golden age of NASA: the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo programs led to the first moon landing in 1969. But it's a mistake to measure the success of our efforts in space by where footprints have been laid. Nor should we make judgments based on how many people follow the progress of our launches or recall the names of our astronauts.

results.abstract: William P Rogers, Republican lawyer who was secretary of state under President Richard M Nixon and attorney general in Eisenhower administration, dies at age 87; photo (L)

headline.main: William P. Rogers, Who Served as Nixon's Secretary of State, Is Dead at 87

results.snippet: William P. Rogers, a suave and well-connected Republican lawyer who was secretary of state under President Richard M. Nixon and attorney general in the Eisenhower administration, died on Tuesday in Bethesda, Md. He was 87.    Mr. Rogers lived in...
results.lead_paragraph: William P. Rogers, a suave and well-connected Republican lawyer who was secretary of state under President Richard M. Nixon and attorney general in the Eisenhower administration, died on Tuesday in Bethesda, Md. He was 87. Mr. Rogers lived in Bethesda and worked in the Washington office of the law firm of Clifford Chance Rogers & Wells, where he was senior partner, until becoming ill several months ago. He suffered from congestive heart failure, his family said.

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has opened, with the same hours as the museum. ''Vikings:...
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has opened, with the same hours as the museum. ''Vikings: The North Atlantic Saga'' details Scandinavian life a millennium ago and focuses on Viking contributions to other civilizations; through Jan. 21. ''Iceland, Land of the Vikings,'' large-format images of Iceland's natural environment; through Jan. 14. ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' live multicolored butterflies from Africa, Asia and the Americas on view in the rain forest of the Butterfly Conservatory; through May 28. Admission: $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $9 for children 2 to 12; under 2, free. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' Tickets: $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $9 for children under 12. In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

results.abstract: Hillary Clinton's new role as senator from New York discussed; her sheer visibility, interests of her prominent state and her deeply held views on issues like education and health care will inevitably bring her to swordpoint with incoming administration (M)

headline.main: The Nation; The Freshman: Starring Hillary Clinton

results.snippet: IF anyone thought that Hillary Rodham Clinton, first lady, bete noire of the right and now New York's favorite adopted daughter, might blend into the woodwork as just another freshman senator, the opening day of Congress ended that fantasy.    During...
results.lead_paragraph: IF anyone thought that Hillary Rodham Clinton, first lady, bete noire of the right and now New York's favorite adopted daughter, might blend into the woodwork as just another freshman senator, the opening day of Congress ended that fantasy. During the hourlong swearing-in ceremony last week, the entire center of gravity in the ornate Senate chamber shifted to the last row of desks, where Mrs. Clinton, in a vivid aqua pants suit, sat nonchalantly whispering like a veteran with Senator John Breaux, the deal-making Louisiana Democrat.

results.abstract: Women make gains in the the male bastion of engineering; gains resonate beyong the profession, since an engineering degree is one of the surest tickets to advancement in America and is already helping propel some women into upper ranks of management; Aine Brazil, one of seven managing principals at Thornton-Tomasetti, comments; photo (M)

headline.main: More Engineers in Hard Hats and Heels

results.snippet: Aine Brazil (pronounced OHNyeh BRAHzil) had plenty of advance warning that engineering was a man's world.    As a student at a Catholic high school for girls in Ireland in the early 1970's, she was one of only three students in an advanced...
results.lead_paragraph: Aine Brazil (pronounced OHNyeh BRAHzil) had plenty of advance warning that engineering was a man's world. As a student at a Catholic high school for girls in Ireland in the early 1970's, she was one of only three students in an advanced mathematics class, a traditional gateway to the profession. Even so, no one thought to encourage her to pursue a career in engineering. ''I didn't have a clue what an engineer did,'' Ms. Brazil said.

results.abstract: Bill Carter article on Mark Burnett, audacious television producer whose first Survivor series pulled in 51 million viewers and single-handedly rejuvenated CBS; Burnett has made sequel and is also working on three other programs: Eco-Challenge and Combat Missions for USA network and Destination Mir, NBC astronaut-training show on which winner gets chance to blast into space; photos; Burnett, 40, grew up in East London and was paratrooper before heading to Los Angeles, where he worked as nanny and used-clothing seller before developing idea of marketing television adventure (M)
results.snippet: Sitting in a CNN studio on Sunset Boulevard, Mark Burnett stretches back in a director's chair, half-smiling as Greta Van Susteren fires off a series of earnest questions about reality TV. Where is it going? How long can the trend last? What does it...
results.lead_paragraph: Sitting in a CNN studio on Sunset Boulevard, Mark Burnett stretches back in a director's chair, half-smiling as Greta Van Susteren fires off a series of earnest questions about reality TV. Where is it going? How long can the trend last? What does it say about our culture? Burnett gazes into the camera like a man surveying his property from a rocking chair on the front porch. This is television, after all, and right now the amiable, supremely confident Burnett seems to be the man holding the deed. Mark Burnett is everywhere these days, which is to be expected for the producer who has changed the way Americans think about television. With ''Survivor,'' Burnett not only pulled in an astonishing 51 million viewers, he also single-handedly rejuvenated CBS. In addition to the sequel, ''Survivor: The Australian Outback'' (which will have its premiere tonight after the Super Bowl on CBS), Burnett is currently producing three other programs, for two other networks. ''Eco-Challenge,'' set to be broadcast in April on the USA cable network, consists of teams of adventure athletes sweating and bleeding, traversing jungles and mountains and caves, in pursuit of a little TV glory and a modest cash prize. In a more militaristic variation on the reality theme, ''Combat Missions,'' also created for USA, features teams of ex-Green Berets, ex-Navy Seals and other elite-force types dropping from helicopters, storming rooftops and braving staged explosions to rescue simulated hostages. The third show, which Burnett has sold to NBC, has the working title ''Destination Mir.'' In this show, the contestant who emerges victorious from the made-for-TV astronaut-training competition wins the opportunity to be strapped inside a Soyuz rocket and blasted into outer space.
